title: William Vousden
text:
<a href="Major-General">Major-General</a> William John Vousden, (20 September 1848 – 12 November 1902) was a <a href="Scotland">Scottish</a> officer in the <a href="British%20Indian%20Army">Indian Army</a>, and recipient of the <a href="Victoria%20Cross">Victoria Cross</a>, the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to <a href="United%20Kingdom">British</a> and <a href="Commonwealth%20of%20Nations">Commonwealth</a> forces.
Military career.
Vousden was born in <a href="Perth%2C%20Scotland">Perth, Scotland</a> the son of Captain Vousden, and was educated at <a href="Kings%20School%20Canterbury">Kings School Canterbury</a>.
He trained at the <a href="Royal%20Military%20College%2C%20Sandhurst">Royal Military College, Sandhurst</a>, and was commissioned into the <a href="35th%20%28Royal%20Sussex%29%20Regiment%20of%20Foot">35th (Royal Sussex) Regiment of Foot</a> in 1864. Promoted to <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> in 1867, and to <a href="Captain%20%28BARM%29">captain</a> in 1876, he transferred to the <a href="5th%20Punjab%20Cavalry">5th Punjab Cavalry</a> where he served in the <a href="Jowaki%20Expedition">Jowaki Expedition</a> 1877–78.
Victoria cross.
He was 34 years old, and a captain in the 5th Punjab Cavalry, during the <a href="Second%20Anglo-Afghan%20War">Second Anglo-Afghan War</a> when the following deed took place on 14 December 1879 on the Koh Asmai Heights, near <a href="Kabul">Kabul</a>, <a href="Afghanistan">Afghanistan</a>, for which he was awarded the Victoria Cross:
Further military service.
He continued to serve in the 5th Punjab Cavalry, was promoted to <a href="Major%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">major</a> in 1884, and took part in further fighting on the <a href="Military%20history%20of%20the%20North-West%20Frontier">North-West Frontier</a> region, for which he was <a href="mentioned%20in%20despatches">mentioned in despatches</a> on 8 June 1891 and 26 January 1898. He was promoted to the <a href="Brevet%20%28military%29">brevet</a> rank of <a href="Colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">colonel</a> in July 1894 and the substantive rank of Colonel of the <a href="Indian%20Staff%20Corps">Indian Staff Corps</a> in January 1899. He was appointed a Companion of the <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Bath">Order of the Bath</a> (CB) in 1900.
In April 1901 he took a command in the <a href="Military%20history%20of%20the%20North-West%20Frontier%23Punjab%20Frontier%20Force">Punjab Frontier Force</a> with the temporary rank of <a href="Brigadier%20general%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">brigadier-general</a>, and shortly thereafter he was granted the local rank of <a href="Major-general%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major general</a>.
He was appointed to act as <a href="Inspector%20General">Inspector General</a> of Cavalry in India from October 1901, in the absence in South Africa of Colonel <a href="Edward%20Locke%20Elliot">Edward Locke Elliot</a>, and received the temporary rank of major general while officiating as such. Following the end of the war in South Africa, Elliott returned in late 1902, and Vousden stepped down.
He died in India of <a href="dysentery">dysentery</a> later the same year, on 12 November 1902 at the age of 54.
Family.
Vousden married, in 1891, a daughter of Major-General Drummond.
